conclusion: Analyze refraction at inner and outer surfaces to determine radius of circular boundary.
Parallel beam of light with cross-sectional radius R is incident on inner surface.
Angle of incidence i is between incident ray and normal to inner surface.
Use Snell's Law at inner surface: n1 sin i = n2 sin r.
n1 is refractive index of air (approximately 1), n2 is refractive index of medium.
Inner surface radius is R, outer surface radius is sqrt(2)R.
Angle theta between refracted ray and axis relates to radius of circular boundary.
Critical angle for total internal reflection: sin theta_c = 1/n2.
Since all light is transmitted, theta <= theta_c.
At outer surface, use Snell's Law: n2 sin theta = n1 sin theta'.
Determine radius r_outer using geometry and angles.
Radius r_outer is sqrt(2)R sin theta.
Final radius of circular boundary is sqrt(2)R.
